metadata.title: Effects of operating parameters and coexisting ions on the efficiency of heavy metal ions removal by nano-fibrous metal-organic framework membrane filtration process

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Science of the Total Environment
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /sc i totenv
Effects of operating parameters and coexisting ions on the efficiency of heavy metal ions removal by nano-fibrous metal-organic framework membrane filtration process
Johnson E. Efome, Dipak Rana ⁎, Takeshi Matsuura, Christopher Q. Lan Industrial Membrane Research Institute, Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, University of Ottawa, 161 Louis Pasteur, Ottawa, ON K1N 6N5, Canada
H I G H L I G H T S G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
• Metal-organic frameworks particles were enmeshed into polyacrylonitrile nanofiber membranes. • The membranes were used for the removal of Pb2+ ions from aqueous solution by adsorption. • The effects of transmembrane pressure, feed conc., and membrane thickness were investigated. • The presence of background ions on adsorption Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+ and Hg2+
ions was studied. • The filtration system could produce N500 L of pure water per m2 of membrane.
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: rana@uottawa.ca (D. Rana).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2019.04.187 0048-9697/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 14 March 2019 Received in revised form 11 April 2019 Accepted 12 April 2019 Available online 14 April 2019
Editor: Huu Hao Ngo
The purification process of wastewater containing heavy metal ions (HMIs) using nano-fibrous metal-organic frameworks, MOF-808, embedded polyacrylonitrile membrane has been studied. The process parameters that were evaluated included feed concentration, transmembrane pressure (TMP), and membrane thickness. The effect of coexisting cations in the solution upon the removal efficiencies of Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+andHg2+ ionswas also investigated. Results from the filtration experiments indicate a substantial variation in the feed volume that the membrane can treat before the permeate lead concentration reaches the allowable limit of 10 ppb, depending on the process parameter. An increase in the membrane thickness showed a significant improvement (26%) with 440 L of the treated feed volume after doubling themembrane layer. An increase in TMP could reduce the treated feed volumeby38%while a decrease in feed concentration led to a 21% increase in the treated feed volume. In the presence of other common background cations in the solution, the removal efficiency of HMIs by adsorption onto MOF-808 dropped by 18 to 37%. This result was dependent upon the HMIs, in the presence of up to three other cations but was minimal in the presence of a single cation indicative of good selectivity.
© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Keywords: Heavy metal ions Coexisting ions Membrane adsorption Metal-organic frameworks Nano-fibrous membrane

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Heavymetal ions (HMIs), even at relatively low concentrations, pose serious long-term health hazards to both the environment and public due to their non-biodegradability, causing them to accumulate in
these systems. With the rising water and air pollution resulting from population increase, it becomes paramount to develop and apply removal techniques to mitigate the effects of heavy metal accumulation. Various physical and chemical treatment processes have been used for treating wastewater and contaminated water. They may be as simple as pH changes (de Pablo et al., 2011) or they use a wide range of adsorbents (Jamshidifard et al., 2019; Cheng et al., 2019; Feng et al., 2018; Pi et al., 2018; Yang et al., 2018; Michel et al., 2018; Wen et al., 2018; Habiba et al., 2017; Uddin, 2017; Zhao et al., 2016), from natural substances (Fakhre and Ibrahim, 2018; Ma et al., 2018; Banerjee et al., 2018; Malamis and Katsou, 2013; Ajmal et al., 2000; Vafakhah et al., 2014; Wang and Peng, 2010; Li and Champagne, 2009; Božić et al., 2009) to 3D complex materials (Pi et al., 2018; Yang et al., 2018; Michel et al., 2018; Wen et al., 2018; Efome et al., 2018a; Efome et al., 2018b; Efome et al., 2018c; Peng et al., 2018; Rudd et al., 2016; Yin et al., 2016; Zheng et al., 2015; Abney et al., 2014). The removal process involving most of these materials is usually governed by their surface area, electrostatic interaction and the level of exposure and contact with the contaminant in the feed. As such, the quantity of the material, as a ratio of the contaminant in feed, could be very large (Fu andWang, 2011). Immobilization on substrates is a method that has been widely used to enhance adsorbent performance through increasing the effective surface area and reducing particle agglomeration. Substrates, although mostly polymeric, have ranged from flat-sheet membranes (Zheng et al., 2015), to ceramic membranes (Wang et al., 2016a), to nano-fibrous membranes (Li et al., 2013; Alcaraz-Espinoza et al., 2015; Feng et al., 2018) and the performance of these materials has been debated compared to the non-immobilized state (Wang et al., 2016a; Li et al., 2013; Alcaraz-Espinoza et al., 2015; Feng et al., 2018).
Practical applicability of these composite membranes has been tested in systems like ultra-filtration (Barakat and Schmidt, 2010), nano-filtration (Rao et al., 2017), and electro-spun nanofibers membranes (Wang et al., 2016a; Li et al., 2013; Alcaraz-Espinoza et al., 2015) to determine their viability in removing HMIs from wastewater and contaminated water. In these filtration processes, there are governing parameters, specifically feed concentration, transmembrane pressure, operating temperature, membrane thickness, and filtration time that determine the performance of the process. These parameters must be carefully evaluated and optimized to harness themaximumpotential of the process. In the HMIs removal processes, the quantity of the contaminant in the feed that can be treated by the system is the point of centricity throughwhichmost of the systems are evaluated. To improve the efficiency of the treatment process, the underlying mechanism (s) and principles must be understood, studied and optimized. In a typical filtration process, a porousmembranewith orwithout fillers is used for a batch or continuous process to produce a permeate of better quality than the feed.
There are two mechanisms of contaminant removal by filtration using the adsorbent embedded membrane. When the membrane pores are smaller than the contaminant species, separation based on size exclusion becomes the prevailing mechanism and usually, there could be a cake formation causing a reduction in flux with time (Efome et al., 2018c; Aydiner et al., 2005). On the other hand, when the membrane pores are larger than the contaminant, removal is controlled by the adsorption affinity of either the membrane surface or the adsorbents immobilized on the membrane. These two mechanisms may work separately or simultaneously.
As such, the rate of the contaminant removal is controlled by the factors whichmay include the filtration transmembrane pressure (TMP), the temperature of the process, the available surface area for adsorption, and the adsorption rate between adsorbent and adsorbate. These factors have been studied for various systems to optimize the filtration process to produce quality permeate (Malamis and Katsou, 2013; Gebreyohannes et al., 2017; Eykens et al., 2016; Mondal et al., 2015). In our earlier research (Efome et al., 2018c), we have developed a mathematical model capable of predicting the treated water quality under certain operating parameters.
We illustrate the effects of somemain filtration parameters like TMP, feed contaminant concentration, and membrane thickness on the volume of feed the system is capable of treating. The study is based on the filtration of lead (Pb2+ ion) from the aqueousmedium. The removal efficiency of various HMIs in preference to the other background cations commonly present in water was also studied. The membrane used in this study was developed in our previous work (Efome et al., 2018a; Efome et al., 2018b) and comprised of a zirconiummetal-organic frameworks, MOF-808, enmeshed in polyacrylonitrile (PAN) nanofibers. In our previous research (Efome et al., 2018c), some studies were done to validate a model. However, in this work, in-depth experimentation has been accomplished. Several membrane configurations have been manufactured and tested for Pb2+, Cd2+, Zn2+, and Hg2+ in an aqueous medium. Also investigated was the effect of coexisting cations, a mixture of Na+, Mg2+, and Ca2+ ions, upon the removal efficiencies of Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+ and Hg2+ ions.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental
sections.text:
The MOF-808 embedded nanofibrous membrane was fabricated based on our previous work (Efome et al., 2018a; Efome et al., 2018b). Zirconium tetrachloride (ZrCl4), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), polyacrylonitrile (PAN) powder and benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3BTC)were purchased from SigmaAldrich Inc. (St. Louis, MO), formic acid from Alfa Aesar (Tewksbury, MA), polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) was donated by Arkema Inc. (Philadelphia, PA). Typically, the MOF808 was prepared as follows: 0.699 g of ZrCl4 and 0.21 g H3BTC were dissolved in amixture of DMF/Formic acid (45/45mL) in a 200-mL boilingflask. Theflaskwas then transferred into amicrowave and irradiated at 400 W for 30 min. The resulting suspension was filtered by centrifugation, washed with DMF three times (10 mL × 3) and dried at 100 °C for 12 h. The dried 0.125 g MOF-808 was primed in 3 g of DMF and then, 0.5 g of PAN was added with the remainder of 2 g solvent to form a suspension with 20 wt% MOF-808 loading. The solution was placed in a shaker for 24 h at 50 °C, degassed and electrospun on aluminium foil at 15–20 kV with a 0.11–0.15 mm/min syringe feed rate, at room temperature and 40% humidity. The collected membranes were room dried to remove excess solvent and then, activated bywashing in acetone and then, water followed by vacuum drying at 100 °C.
It should be noted that the membrane used for the filtration experiment was comprised of the following two layers; the top PAN nanofibrous membrane with the embedded MOF-808 and the bottom PVDF nanofibrous membrane. The top PAN/MOF-808 membrane controls the heavy metal adsorption due to the presence of adsorbent MOF-808 and the bottom PVDF membrane controls the flux due to its hydrophobic property. As such, the thickness of themembrane referred to here represents solely that of the PAN/MOF-808 layer. The PVDF layer thicknesswas unchanged tomaintain the constant permeation rate. The filtration experiments were carried out using a continuous filtration setup with a 7 L reservoir which was connected to a feed pump. A feed flow rate of 1.5 LPM was maintained. It is noted that the feed concentration of Pb2+ concentration was 25 or 50 ppb. The filtration set up was shown in our earlier work (Efome et al., 2018c). The effect of the applied TMP was investigated at a constant feed concentration of 50 or 25 ppb using a single layer of PAN/MOF-808 on the PVDF base layer at room temperature. A specified volume of permeate was collected at predetermined time intervals and the permeate sample was subjected to flame atomic absorption spectrophotometry (iCE 3000, Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., Waltham, MA) to measure the heavy metal (Pb2+) ion concentration. It is noted that the iCE 3000 has a single atomizerwith a fully automatic gas box. The conditions for the single lead ion filtration are summarized in Table 1.
The filtration protocol is the same in the presence of the coexisting ions (CIs), where the mixture of Na+, Mg2+, and Ca2+ (47.9, 49.3, and 50.5 ppm, respectively) was added to the feed solution.
A single PAN/MOF-808membrane was used at 0.1 bar TMP. The calibration plots of HMIs (Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+ andHg2+) and CIs (Na+,Mg2+ and Ca2+) are shown in the Supplementary information. The adsorption experiments were carried out following the protocol described thoroughly in the earlier research (Efome et al., 2018a; Efome et al., 2018b). Briefly, 1 ppm of Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+ and Hg2+ (ZnCl2, CdCl2, Pb (NO3)2, and HgCl2) solutionswere preparedwithout andwith the addition of the CIs, either individually or simultaneously. 20mg of MOF-808 particles was added to 30 mL of the prepared solution and after 3 h, the HMIs concentrationwasmeasured. However, in the case of PAN nanofibers or PAN/MOF-808 nanofibers, 100mg nanofiberswere used instead of 20 mg.
The membrane's mechanical properties were obtained using the standard method ASTM D 882 with Instron Electropuls E3000 (Instron, Norwood, MA) equipment at room temperature and a crosshead speed of 5 mm/min (ASTM D 882, 1995). The specimens were rectangular strips of film, specifically with a thickness of 60–90 μm, width of 10 mm and length of 20 mm. The tensile stress-strain curves were obtained for the samples with a final rupture of at least 2 mm from the edge of the clamps. Inhomogeneous samples were rejected and only stress-strain results from samples with breakage of at least 2 mm from the edges were selected.

sections.heading: 3.1. Effect of transmembrane pressure (TMP)
sections.text:
The typical breakthrough curves of the membrane filtration are shown in Fig. 1. During the initial lag period, the lead ion concentration in the permeate is maintained nearly equal to zero due to the strong adsorption capacity of the PAN/MOF-808 layer. After the lag period, the lead concentration starts to increase since the adsorption site is largely saturated with the lead ions. The figure shows that the lag period decreases with an increase in TMP. This is because the membrane flux increases with an increase in TMP according to the Darcy's equation (Ke
et al., 2008; Choong et al., 2014) and the amount of lead ions that can be treated by the PAN/MOF-808 layer is supplied to the membrane within a shorter period. At 0.1 bar, the membrane could treat 520 L (normalized per m2 of the membrane) of feed before the permeate lead concentration reached the maximum allowable concentration of 10 ppb. This volume is called hereafter the “concentration effect volume”. Upon doubling the TMP to 0.2 bar, the concentration effect volume was reduced to 320 L (38% reduction). The decrease in contact time between the aqueous feed and MOF-808 particles at the higher TMP may also account for the appearance of heavy metal ions earlier in the breakthrough curve as reported elsewhere (Furukawa et al., 2008). This increase in pressure will not be sufficient to cause any mechanical deformations on the membrane since the membrane showed relatively high Young's modulus and stress at break values (Fig. 2).
An increase in TMP also has the tendency to cause themembrane to suffer from compaction (Zedel et al., 2017; Cai et al., 2008) which leads to a reduction in porosity. However, in the presence of the PAN/MOF808 layer on top of the flux controlling PVDF layer, the effect of compaction of PVDF layer on the permeate flux was minimized.
It is desirable to increase the flux to treat a large amount of contaminated water within a shorter period. Increasing the TMP is one way of increasing the flux and another way is to reduce the thickness of the flux controlling the PVDF layer. In both ways, however, the concentration effect volume decreases, which results in the shorter interval between membrane regenerations. Hence, the optimization of
membrane thickness and operating pressure is necessary to find out the balance between these two opposing requirements.

sections.heading: 3.2. Effect of feed concentration
sections.text:
In treatment centers, seasonal changes and the location of the treatment facility may affect the feed concentration of the wastewater or water to be treated. It is, therefore, important to understand the functionality of the membrane at varied feed concentrations in order to
Fig. 5. Effects of coexisting ions on the removal efficiency of heavymetal ions byMOF-808 partic coexisting ions at approx. 50 ppm each.
meet the treatment requirements. The effect of the applied TMP was studied at a constant feed concentration of 50 or 25 ppb using a single layer of PAN/MOF-808 on the PVDF base layer at room temperature. With the initial feed concentration of 50 ppb, Fig. 3 shows that when the concentration is reduced by half, the membrane can treat more of the feed.
From the Fig. 3, at 50 ppb feed solution, the concentration effect volumeof the single-layeredmembranewas 580 Lwhile it was 700 Lwhen the concentration was reduced by 50%, representing about a 21% increase. When the concentration reduces, the amount of heavy metal ions that come to contact with the PAN/MOF-808 membrane also reduces, which delays the saturation of the adsorbent. The membrane was expected to treat more feed at half the original feed concentration but with just a 21% increase, it is most likely that some parts of the membrane might not be in full contact with the feed solution. This will imply that the adsorbent MOF-808 particles were not completely used for adsorption.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of membrane thickness
sections.text:
It must be noted that the change in membrane thickness investigated refers to the change in the PAN/MOF-808 layer which was varied from single to doubled layer with the PVDF layer thickness kept constant at all times. Increasing the membrane thickness is usually associated with an increase in mass resistance which should reduce the flux at constant operating pressure (Konishi et al., 1996; Shao et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2016b). However, as already mentioned, the flux does not change even when the PAN/MOF-808 layer thickness is changed, since the PVDF layer is flux controlling. The effect of doubling the PAN/
les: a) Zn2+, b) Cd2+, c) Pb2+ and d)Hg2+ ions. The cocktail solution comprised of all three
MOF-808 layer thickness on the breakthrough curve is illustrated in Fig. 4. We have used membrane thicknesses around 530 and 1060 μm.
For a single layer membrane, 350 L of treated solution can be produced compared to 440 L for a double layer membrane corresponding to a 26% increase. Since it is estimated that every PAN layer contains approximately 20 wt% MOF-808, doubling the PAN layer should correspond to close to double the MOF-808 quantity available for adsorption. With only a 26% increase, it is an indication that not all of the MOF-808 particles were available for adsorption, a phenomenon earlier reported (Efome et al., 2018a). Not limiting to the availability of the MOF-808 for adsorption, particle agglomeration in the nanofiber membrane could be another contributing factor in reducing the available adsorption sites for adsorption.

sections.heading: 3.4. Effect of coexisting cations
sections.text:
The presence of other coexisting ions (CIs) like Na+,Mg2+, and Ca2+ inwastewater is inevitable, and therefore, their effect on the removal efficiency of theMOF-808 for HMIs, including Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+ and Hg2+ was assessed. Adsorption experiments were carried out using theMOF808 particles (Fig. 5), the neat PAN nanofibers (Fig. 6) and the enmeshed PAN/MOF-808 nanofibers membranes (Fig. 7). The removal efficiencies by MOF-808 are shown in Fig. 5a, b, c and d for Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+ and Hg2+ ions, respectively. From Fig. 5, the removal efficiency decreased in the presence of all CIs. In particular, the removal efficiency was the lowest in the presence of the mixture of all CIs (shown as cocktail).
Although the reduction in removal efficiencies of HMIs is observed in the presence of the CIs, the preferential adsorption of HMIs is quite
Fig. 6. Effects of coexisting ions on the removal efficiency of heavymetal ions by PAN nanofiber coexisting ions at approx. 50 ppm each.
obvious. Otherwise, the reduction would be much greater. The preferential adsorption of HMIs can be explained by their Pauling electronegativities (1.65, 1.69, 1.87 and 2.00 for Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+ and Hg2+, respectively) which are absolutely higher than any of the CIs [Na+ (0.93), Mg2+ (1.31), and Ca2+ (1.00)] (Ohwada, 1984; Ohwada, 1983). Therefore, the HMIs are more strongly bound to the anionic adsorption sites than the CIs due to the electrostatic attractive forces. The electronegativity can not necessarily explain the changes among the HMIs. For example, the order of removal efficiency among the HMIs in the absence of CI is Zn2+ (54%) N Cd2+ (50%) N Pb2+ (46%) N Hg2+ (34%), which is precisely the opposite of the increasing order of the electronegativity, i.e. Zn2+ (1.65) b Cd2+ (1.69) b Pb2+ (1.87) b Hg2+ (2.00). If the electronegativity is the sole governing factor, the removal efficiency should increase with the increase in electronegativity. Hence, there should be another factor that contributing to the removal efficiency.
Considering the ionic radius of the HMIs, the order is Zn2+ (0.74 Å) b Cd2+ (0.95 Å) b Hg2+ (1.02 Å) b Pb2+ (1.19 Å) (Lide, 1992). The removal efficiency tends to decrease as the ionic radius increases, except for the interchange of the positions of Pb2+ and Hg2+. This implies that there seems to be a steric effect of the ions that shields the approach of HMIs to the adsorption site. The above interpretation becomes more likely when the electrostatic pull into the narrow MOF channel plays a role in the adsorption mechanism (Efome et al., 2018a; Efome et al., 2018b). This also implies that the larger Pb2+ andHg2+ ions tend to hinder the competitive adsorption of CIs more than the smaller Zn2+ and Cd2+ ions. This is similar to the results reported earlier by Tan et al. (2016). As for the reduction in the removal efficiency order: Cd2+ (37%) N Zn2+ (32%) N Hg2+ (29%) N Pb2+ (18%). Thus, the removal
s: a) Zn2+, b) Cd2+, c) Pb2+ and d) Hg2+ ions. The cocktail solution comprised of all three
efficiencies of HMIs and their reduction in the presence of CIs can be explained by the interplay of the electronegativity and the ionic radius of the HMIs.
Fig. 6 shows the removal efficiency of the HMIs by the neat PAN nanofibers. Compared with Fig. 5 for MOF-808, it is obvious that a similar trend was observed, i.e. the adsorption capacity decreases progressively in the presence of the higher CI concentration. Except for in the case of Hg2+ whose adsorption capacity is less in the presence of CIs, but increases as the CI concentration increases. As for the adsorption capacities in the absence of CIs, they are much less thanMOF-808 and the order among theHMIs has changed considerably, i.e. Pb2+ (22%) N Cd2+ (20%) N Zn2+ (12.5%) NHg2+ (12%), showing the interchange of the positions between Pb2+ and Zn2+. The above order is difficult to explain by the electronegativity and ionic radius, since PAN contains no ions and the polymer segments are more flexible than the rigidMOF framework. Although there are a number of studies onHMIs adsorption bymodified PAN nanofibers, hardly any reports are found on the adsorption by neat PANnanofibers in the literature. However, themaximumadsorption capacity of Pb2+ (48.67mg/g) higher than that of Cd2+ (5.99mg/g) by the neat PAN nanofiber was recently reported by Haddad and Alharbi (2019), which coincides with the order observed in our work. As for the low removal efficiency of Zn2+ ions by PAN, however, no data are found in the literature to support our observation. Fig. 7 shows the removal efficiencies of PAN/MOF-808 composite nanofibers. The removal efficiencies of HMIs are in the following descending order: Pb2+ (47%) N Cd2+ (42%) N Zn2+ (37%) N Hg2+ (29%). It should be noted that the above removal efficiencies are between those of neat PAN (Fig. 6) and MOF-808 (Fig. 5), except for the data of Pb2+, and the order is the same as that for the neat PAN. Therefore, the effects of both PAN and MOF-808 are clearly observed in the composite nanofiber.
Fig. 7. Effects of coexisting ions on the removal efficiency of heavy metal ions by PAN/MOF-80 comprised of all three coexisting ions at approx. 50 ppm each.
These results support the fact that the enmeshed MOF-808 is still available for adsorption, but there is resistance to contact between the MOF-808 particles/HMIs arising from the polymer boundary and from particles agglomeration. Interestingly, the removal efficiency of Hg2+ increases again with the increase in the concentration of CIs.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
PAN/MOF-808 nanofibers membranes were prepared by coelectrospinning ofMOF-808 and PANpolymer, and then used as adsorption filters for removal of Pb2+ ions to study the effect of the various process parameters, specifically TMP, feed contaminant concentration, and membrane thickness. The volume of the feed treated before the Pb2+ ions concentration reached the maximum allowable limit in drinking water (10 ppb) was determined at different TMPs, membrane thicknesses, initial feed concentrations in the presence and of CIs. It was also found that the HMIs adsorption capacity of MOF-808 was reduced only moderately, i.e. 18–37%, in the presence of other background ions. This slight reduction of 18–37% could be due to the preference of theMOF-808 toHMIs or also because the active sites acting in a different phenomenon that could be studied in greater detail.
It was observed that lowing the TMP, reducing the initial feed concentration, and increasing themembrane thickness had the greatest impact in increasing the treatable feed volume. The enmeshed MOF-808 particles are available in the PAN/MOF-808 composite nanofibers for adsorption of HMIs. However, there is resistance to contact between the MOF-808 particles/HMIs arising from the polymer boundary and fromparticles agglomeration. Ourwork therefore provides a fundamental foundation for understanding and developing nanofibrous MOF membranes (NMOM) systems for the processing of contaminated
8 particles nanofibers: a) Zn2+, b) Cd2+, c) Pb2+ and d) Hg2+ ions. The cocktail solution
water. Ongoing work in our research will include the testing of the NMOM system for other complex contaminant solutions like nuclear processed water or processed water from the mining industry and for developing an in-depth understanding of the background ion effects.
Conflicts of interest
The authors declare no conflict of interest.

Practical applicability of these composite membranes has been tested in systems like ultra-filtration (Barakat and Schmidt, 2010), nano-filtration (Rao et al.

, 2017), and electro-spun nanofibers membranes (Wang et al., 2016a; Li et al., 2013; Alcaraz-Espinoza et al., 2015) to determine their viability in removing HMIs from wastewater and contaminated water.

When the membrane pores are smaller than the contaminant species, separation based on size exclusion becomes the prevailing mechanism and usually, there could be a cake formation causing a reduction in flux with time (Efome et al., 2018c; Aydiner et al., 2005).

These factors have been studied for various systems to optimize the filtration process to produce quality permeate (Malamis and Katsou, 2013; Gebreyohannes et al., 2017; Eykens et al., 2016; Mondal et al., 2015).

These factors have been studied for various systems to optimize the filtration process to produce quality permeate (Malamis and Katsou, 2013; Gebreyohannes et al., 2017; Eykens et al., 2016; Mondal et al., 2015).

These factors have been studied for various systems to optimize the filtration process to produce quality permeate (Malamis and Katsou, 2013; Gebreyohannes et al., 2017; Eykens et al., 2016; Mondal et al., 2015).

The decrease in contact time between the aqueous feed and MOF-808 particles at the higher TMP may also account for the appearance of heavy metal ions earlier in the breakthrough curve as reported elsewhere (Furukawa et al., 2008).
An increase in TMP also has the tendency to cause themembrane to suffer from compaction (Zedel et al., 2017; Cai et al., 2008) which leads to a reduction in porosity.
An increase in TMP also has the tendency to cause themembrane to suffer from compaction (Zedel et al., 2017; Cai et al., 2008) which leads to a reduction in porosity.

Increasing the membrane thickness is usually associated with an increase in mass resistance which should reduce the flux at constant operating pressure (Konishi et al., 1996; Shao et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2016b).

Increasing the membrane thickness is usually associated with an increase in mass resistance which should reduce the flux at constant operating pressure (Konishi et al., 1996; Shao et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2016b).

metadata.abstractText: • Metal-organic frameworks particles were enmeshed into polyacrylonitrile nanofiber membranes. • The membranes were used for the removal of Pb ions from aqueous solu-
